member.name: T:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog
member.summary: A task dialog is the successor of the message box and provides a lot more features.
member.remarks:
For more information, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/Controls/task-dialogs-overview
Note: To use a task dialog, the application needs to be compiled with a manifest that contains a dependency to Microsoft.Windows.Common-Controls (6.0.0.0), and the thread needs to use the single-threaded apartment (STA) model.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.ContinueButtonClickHandlingMessage
member.summary: A self-defined window message that we post to the task dialog when handling a notification, so that we will ignore further notifications until we process the posted message.
member.remarks:
This is used to work-around a bug in the native task dialog, where a notification seems to be sent twice to the callback when you "click" a button by pressing its access key (mnemonic) and the dialog is still open when continuing the message loop.
This work-around should not have negative effects, such as erroneously ignoring a valid button clicked notification when the user presses the button multiple times while the GUI thread is hangs - this seems to work correctly, as our posted message will be processed before further (valid) notifications are processed.
See: https://gist.github.com/kpreisser/335fde8934da1e0c150fe71ee5ead433
Note: We use a WM_APP message with a high value (WM_USER is not appropriate as it is private to the control class), in order to avoid conflicts with WM_APP messages which other parts of the application might want to send when they also subclassed the dialog window, although that should be unlikely.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.s_callbackProcDelegate
member.remarks: We must store this delegate (and prevent it from being garbage-collected) to ensure the function pointer doesn't become invalid.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.s_callbackProcDelegatePtr
member.summary: The function pointer created from .

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog._waitingNavigationPages
member.summary: A qeueue of s that have been bound by navigating the dialog, but don't yet reflect the state of the native dialog because the corresponding notification was not yet received.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog._hwndDialog
member.summary: Window handle of the task dialog when it is being shown.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog._instanceHandlePtr
member.summary: The of a that represents this instance.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog._raisedOpened
member.summary: Stores a value that indicates if the event has been called and so the event can be called later.
member.remarks: This is used to prevent raising the event without raising the event first (e.g. if the dialog cannot be shown due to an invalid icon).

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog._raisedPageCreated
member.summary: Stores a value that indicates if the event has been called for the current and so the corresponding can be called later.
member.remarks: This is used to prevent raising the event without raising the event first (e.g. if navigation fails).

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog._buttonClickNavigationCounter
member.summary: A counter which is used to determine whether the dialog has been navigated while being in a handler.
member.remarks:
When the dialog navigates within a ButtonClicked handler, the handler should always return S_FALSE to prevent the dialog from applying the button that raised the handler as dialog result. Otherwise, this can lead to memory access problems like s, especially if the previous dialog page had radio buttons (but the new ones do not).
See the comment in for more information.
When the dialog navigates, it sets the navigationIndex to the current stackCount value, so that the ButtonClicked handler can determine if the dialog has been navigated after it was called. Tracking the stack count and navigation index is necessary as there can be multiple ButtonClicked handlers on the call stack, for example if a ButtonClicked handler runs the message loop so that new click events can be processed.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog._resultButton
member.summary:
The button designated as the dialog result by the handler for the
notification.
member.remarks:
This will be set the first time the handler returns to cache the button instance, so that can then return it.
Additionally, this is used to check if there was already a handler that returned , so that further handles will return to not override the previously set result.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog._isInNavigate
member.summary: Specifies if the current code is called from within .

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog._ignoreButtonClickedNotifications
member.summary: Specifies if the method should currently ignore notifications.
member.remarks: See for more information.

member.name: E:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.Opened
member.summary: Occurs after the task dialog has been created but before it is displayed.
member.remarks:
You can use this event to allocate resources associated with the task dialog window handle, as it is the first event where is available.
Note: The dialog will not show until this handler returns (even if the handler would run the message loop).

member.name: E:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.Shown
member.summary: Occurs when the task dialog is first displayed.

member.name: E:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.Closing
member.summary: Occurs when the task dialog closing.
member.remarks:
You can cancel the close by setting to true. Otherwise, the dialog window will close, and the event will be raised afterwards.
Note: The event might not be called immediately after the event (even though the dialog window has already closed). This can happen for example when showing multiple (modeless) dialogs at the same time and then closing the one that was shown first â€“ in that case, the event for that dialog will be called only after the second dialog is also closed.
Note: This event might not always be called, e.g. if navigation of the dialog fails; however, the event will always be called.

member.name: E:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.Closed
member.summary: Occurs when the task dialog is closed.
member.remarks: You can use this event to free resources associated with the task dialog window handle, as it is the last event where is available.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.Handle
member.summary: Gets the window handle of the task dialog window, or if the dialog is currently not being shown.
member.remarks: When showing the dialog, the handle will be available first when the event occurs, and last when the event occurs after which you shouldn't use it any more.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.Page
member.summary: Gets or sets the instance that contains the contents which this task dialog will display.
member.remarks:
When setting this property while the task dialog is displayed, it will recreate its contents from the specified ("navigation"). This means that the event will occur for the current page, and after the dialog completed navigation, the event of the new page will occur.
Please note that you cannot manipulate the task dialog or its controls immediately after navigating it (except for calling or navigating the dialog again). You will need to wait for the event to occur before you can manipulate the dialog or its controls.
Note that when navigating the dialog, the new page will be bound immediately, but the previous page will not be unbound until the event of the new page is raised, because during that time the task dialog behaves as if it still showed the controls of the previous page.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.DoNotSetForeground
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates if the task dialog should not set itself as foreground window when showing it.
member.remarks:
When setting this property to true and then showing the dialog, it causes the dialog to net set itself as foreground window. This means that if currently none of the application's windows has focus, the task dialog doesn't try to "steal" focus (which otherwise can result in the task dialog window being activated, or the taskbar button for the window flashing orange). However, if the application already has focus, the task dialog window will be activated anyway.
Note: This property only has an effect on Windows 8 and higher.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.DialogIsShown
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether is currently being called.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.HandleAvailable
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the native task dialog window has been created and its handle is available using the property.
member.remarks: This property can only be true if is also true. However, normally this property should be equivalent to , because when showing the dialog, the callback should have been called setting the handle.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.RadioButtonClickedStackCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the current count of stack frames that are in the event for the current task dialog.
member.remarks: This is used by the setter so that it can disallow the change when the count is greater than zero. Additionally, it is used to deny navigation of the task dialog in that case.

member.summary: Closes the shown task dialog with a result.
member.remarks: To close the dialog with a different result, call the method of the which you want to set as result.

member.name: M:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.SwitchProgressBarMode(System.Boolean)
member.summary: While the dialog is being shown, switches the progress bar mode to either a marquee progress bar or to a regular progress bar. For a marquee progress bar, you can enable or disable the marquee using .

member.name: M:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialog.SetProgressBarMarquee(System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: While the dialog is being shown, enables or disables progress bar marquee when an marquee progress bar is displayed.
member.param: The time in milliseconds between marquee animation updates. If 0, the animation will be updated every 30 milliseconds.

member.remarks: The default range is 0 to 100.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.CustomButtonStartID

member.remarks: We need to ensure we don't use a ID that is already used for a standard button (TaskDialogResult), so we start with 100 to be safe (100 is also used as first ID in MSDN examples for the task dialog).

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.RadioButtonStartID
member.summary: The start ID for radio buttons.
member.remarks: This must be at least 1 because 0 already stands for "no button".

member.name: E:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.Created
member.summary: Occurs after this instance is bound to a task dialog and the task dialog has created the GUI elements represented by this instance.
member.remarks: This will happen after showing or navigating the dialog.

member.name: E:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.Destroyed
member.summary: Occurs when the task dialog is about to destroy the GUI elements represented by this instance and it is about to be unbound from the task dialog.
member.remarks: This will happen when closing or navigating the dialog.

member.name: E:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.Help

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.Width

member.summary: Gets or sets the that specifies how to display custom buttons.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.AllowCancel
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the task dialog can be canceled by pressing ESC, Alt+F4 or clicking the title bar's close button even if no button is specified in .
member.remarks: You can intercept cancellation of the dialog without displaying a "Cancel" button by adding a with its set to false and specifying a result.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.RightToLeftLayout
member.remarks: Note that once a task dialog has been opened with or has navigated to a where this flag is set, it will keep on subsequent navigations to a new even when it doesn't have this flag set.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.CanBeMinimized
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the task dialog can be minimized when it is shown modeless.
member.remarks: When setting this property to true, is automatically implied.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.SizeToContent
member.summary: Indicates that the width of the task dialog is determined by the width of its content area (similar to Message Box sizing behavior).
member.remarks: This flag is ignored if is not set to 0.

member.name: P:KPreisser.UI.TaskDialogPage.WaitingForInitialization
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates if the started navigation to this page but navigation did not yet complete (in which case we cannot modify the dialog even though we are bound).

member.remarks: This property can be set while the dialog is shown. However, it is not possible to change the state from to any other state, and vice versa.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates if this should be shown when displaying the Task Dialog.
member.remarks: Setting this to false allows you to still receive the event (e.g. for the button when is set), or to call the method even if the button is not shown.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.WindowSubclassHandler._windowProcDelegate
member.summary: The delegate for the callback handler (that calls from which the native function pointer is created.
member.remarks:
We must store this delegate (and prevent it from being garbage-collected) to ensure the function pointer doesn't become invalid.
Note: We create a new delegate (and native function pointer) for each instance because even though creation will be slower (and requires a bit of memory to store the native code) it will be faster when the window procedure is invoked, because otherwise we would need to use a dictionary to map the hWnd to the instance, as the window procedure doesn't allow to store reference data. However, this is also the way that the NativeWindow class of WinForms does it.

member.name: F:KPreisser.UI.WindowSubclassHandler._windowProcDelegatePtr
member.summary: The function pointer created from .

member.name: M:KPreisser.UI.WindowSubclassHandler.Open
member.summary: Subclasses the window.
member.remarks: You must call to undo the subclassing before the window is destroyed.
